<SEG id="segment-25" start_char="3720" end_char="3825">
  <ORIGINAL_TEXT>The risk is latent, because the virus can remain active, without manifesting itself, in any of the guests.</ORIGINAL_TEXT>
  <TOKEN id="segment-25-0" pos="word" morph="none" start_char="3720" end_char="3722">The</TOKEN>
  <TOKEN id="segment-25-1" pos="word" morph="none" start_char="3724" end_char="3727">risk</TOKEN>

<SEG id="segment-26" start_char="3828" end_char="4031">
  <ORIGINAL_TEXT>All are considered by the authorities as suspected of having the disease, and for this stage of risk there is treatment and a protocol that will prevent its spread to family members and other Venezuelans.</ORIGINAL_TEXT>

<SEG id="segment-1" start_char="52" end_char="304">
  <ORIGINAL_TEXT>The Dominican government confirmed yesterday that nine people, seven Venezuelans and two Dominicans, became infected with cholera by consuming a lobster that was served during a wedding that took place last Saturday in the eastern region of the country.</ORIGINAL_TEXT>
  <TOKEN id="segment-1-0" pos="word" morph="none" start_char="52" end_char="54">The</TOKEN>

<SEG id="segment-1" start_char="79" end_char="259">

  <TOKEN id="segment-1-5" pos="word" morph="none" start_char="118" end_char="121">that</TOKEN>

en.L0C04FPK3: Cholera blamed on lobster at Dominican wedding    Health officials say contaminated lobster has given cholera to dozens of guests who attended a lavish wedding in the Dominican Republic. Most of the nearly 500 guests flew in from Venezuela, and that country's health minister says Thursday that 37 of them have tested positive for cholera. Eugenia Sader says four guests from Madrid, Mexico and Boston also have the disease. The ill also include Dominican businessman Fernando Hazoury, whose family owns Cap Cana resort. Dominican Health minister Bautista Rojas says lobsters for Saturday's wedding at an exclusive community were bought in Pedernales. That town borders Haiti, where more than 3,000 people have died from a cholera epidemic.
en.L0C04FPK2: 6 Mass. Residents Contract Cholera In Dominican Republic   BOSTON (AP) – The Massachusetts health department says six state residents have tested positive for cholera after attending a wedding in the Dominican Republic earlier this month.  Department spokeswoman Julia Hurley said Friday that all the patients have been released from local hospitals, and health officials aren’t concerned the disease will spread.  READ MORE:  Officials in the Dominican Republic said the guests became infected after eating contaminated lobster at the Jan. 22 wedding in the exclusive community of Casa de Campo. More than 110 cases have been reported in Venezuela, where many of the 452 guests live. Other guests were also treated in Spain, Mexico and the Dominican Republic.  READ MORE:  The Massachusetts cases include a man, a young woman and a father and his three children.  MORE NEWS:  (© Copyright 2011 The Associated Press. All Rights Reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.)
en.L0C04FPKD: Cholera hits Dominican Republic resort   A lavish party at a luxury resort with golf, horse riding, swimming pools and lobster: not the typical setting for a cholera outbreak.  Casa de Campo, a five-star complex in the Dominican Republic, has been hit by the disease which has swept though slums and villages in neighbouring Haiti [see footnote].  Dozens of international guests at a family celebration – some reports said it was a wedding – were stricken with vomiting and diarrhoea after eating apparently contaminated lobster.  Dominican health officials said that at least 37 of the 500 guests had tested positive for cholera, including Fernando Hazoury, whose family owns a separate luxury resort, and guests from Spain, Mexico and the US.  The health minister, Bautista Rojas, said lobsters for last Saturday's wedding came from Pedernales, a town bordering Haiti, where about 3,800 have died and 189,000 fallen ill since October.  The disease, a south Asian strain suspected to have originated with Nepalese UN peacekeepers stationed in central Haiti, is transmitted by contaminated faeces in water sources. Dehydrated victims can die within hours, but symptoms are easily treated.  At least 21 Venezuelans who attended the event have been hospitalised, according to Venezuela's health minister, Eugenia Sader. The disease was under control and Venezuelans had no cause for concern, she added.  "We want to inform the nation that it must remain calm because all the cases we have are of those who attended a family gathering in Dominican Republic."  This footnote was appended on 1 February 2011. Casa de Campo has asked us to make clear that it is aware of the situation resulting from a private event with an outside caterer held at the resort. The F department, guests and staff at the resort were and still are unaffected, as the caterer is not affiliated with Casa de Campo and the event was hosted in a privately owned villa.  … we have a small favour to ask. en.L0C04FPK4: Cholera Prompts Dominican Republic to Burn Uncertified Food From Haiti    PORT-AU-PRINCE, HAITI - FEBRUARY 18: Children light fires to burn the coatings off of wires they have scavenged from destroyed buildings in order to sell the exposed metal, February 18, 2011 in Port-au-Prince, Haiti. Children all across Haiti work daily to earn what little income they can manage. (Photo by Allison Shelley/Getty Images)   (2011 Getty Images)  The Dominican Republic says any fresh meat and seafood from Haiti not stamped with a certificate claiming it’s free of cholera will be burned.  Health Minister Bautista Rojas says the measure is intended to prevent cholera from spreading through the informal trading network between the two neighboring countries.  Rojas said Monday the military has been authorized to seize and destroy uncertified raw animal products.  Dominican authorities blame lobster from Haiti for sickening dozens of people at a lavish Casa de Campo wedding last month. Guests had flown in from Venezuela, Boston, New York and Madrid for the wedding, attended by about 500 people.  The Dominican Republic says three people have died and 400 sickened from cholera, a water-borne disease, since October. In Haiti, cholera has killed more than 4,500 people and sickened 234,000.  Based on reporting by The Associated Press.
en.L0C04FPK0: Cholera alert reaches Venezuela via Dominican Republic   Cholera is spread by contaminated food or water   More than 20 Venezuelans have contracted cholera after visiting the Dominican Republic, the Venezuelan health ministry has said.  The patients were taken to hospital in Caracas after showing symptoms and were being kept in quarantine.  They had travelled to the Dominican Republic for a wedding.  Cholera reached the Dominican Republic last November from neighbouring Haiti, where an epidemic has killed almost 4,000 people.  A number of other Venezuelans are also thought to have the disease.  "The people must remain calm because all those infected had attended a family gathering in the Dominican Republic," said Venezuelan Health Minister Eugenia Sader.  She added that Venezuela had sufficient medical supplies to treat 10,000 cholera cases.  The Dominican Republic has recorded 238 cases of cholera and registered its first cholera death last Sunday. The victim was a 53-year-old Haitian man.  In Haiti, almost 200,000 people have been infected since the epidemic broke out in October, but aid agencies say the rate of infection has slowed.  For Haiti and the Dominican Republic, which share the island of Hispaniola, it is the first cholera outbreak in more than a century.  Venezuela, in contrast, has suffered occasional outbreaks in recent decades.  Cholera is a bacterial disease spread by contaminated drinking water or food, but is treatable with oral or intravenous rehydration and antibiotics.  Related Internet Links   Venezuelan health ministry (in Spanish)  World Health Organisation   The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.
en.L0C04FPK1: 2d cholera case confirmed   The destination was shimmering: a five-star, palm tree-studded resort in the Caribbean. The occasion was joyous: a lavish wedding with a guest roster stretching more than 400 names long.   At least two of those who became ill hail from Massachusetts. First, there was a 30-year-old man who sought treatment Tuesday in the emergency room at Massachusetts General Hospital. Then there were more: Disease trackers said yesterday that a second Massachusetts resident had been diagnosed with the intestinal ailment and four others in the state are suspected of having it.  All are recovering, and there is no evidence the disease is spreading in Massachusetts, said Dr. Larry Madoff, a top epidemiologist at the Massachusetts Department of Public Health.  The emergence of cholera in Boston, 1,700 miles from the origin of an outbreak moving across the island of Hispaniola, il lustrates the swift, relentless migration of infectious diseases in an era of widespread jet traffic.  "We fully expected this,’’ said Dr. Jordan Tappero, incident manager for the cholera outbreak response at the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta. "We’re not at all surprised that this would happen, given all the travel.’’  Guests flew to the Dominican Republic from distant points for the extravagant wedding last weekend. There were visitors from Venezuela and Spain — and Boston. By the dozens, they became sick after returning home, stricken with the hallmark symptoms of cholera: diarrhea and vomiting.  The man treated at Mass. General endured multiple bowel movements for a day and a half, although he had neither a fever nor bloody stool, both symptoms of more severe infection. He was given oral rehydration and antibiotics and sent home.  A young woman arrived at the Brigham and Women’s Hospital emergency room on Wednesday. She, too, was rehydrated and sent home, said Erin McDonough, spokeswoman for the Brigham. Preliminary testing found that the woman, who was not identified because of patient confidentiality laws, had cholera.  "The physician I spoke with said there’s very little concern with cholera cases in the US because of the availability of medications and clean water,’’ McDonough said. "It’s unlikely there would be any transmission.’’  A father and his three children are also suspected of having the bacterial condition, said Madoff, adding that disease specialists are awaiting laboratory tests on at least one member of that family before a firm diagnosis can be made.  "We’re certainly very suspicious that one or more of the family members may turn out to be positive,’’ Madoff said. That family, he said, was "in the same setting where we know everybody else acquired it.’’  That setting was the Casa de Campo resort, a popular Caribbean destination. The timing of symptoms among wedding guests suggested they caught the germs in the Dominican Republic.  The source of the outbreak is unknown. It has been reported that guests dined on lobster, and shellfish can harbor the germs. But if food is cooked thoroughly, the risk of infection should be mitigated. Cholera most often spreads through tainted water or sewage but can be conveyed by contaminated food.  The resort issued a statement saying that while it "deeply regrets the food poisoning/cholera cases that recently occurred during an exclusive wedding party in a private villa residence within our resort,’’ the food, drinks, and ice were provided by an outside catering company hired by the party’s hosts.  The cholera strain circulating in the Dominican Republic has been linked to an epidemic in Haiti that has killed more than 3,000 since October. Before the cluster of patients in Massachusetts, federal disease detectives had identified 10 cholera cases in the United States they believe are linked to the island of Hispaniola, shared by Haiti and the Dominican Republic.
en.L0C04G4DT: Venezuela faces the "anger of the rich"  image copyrightAFP  Caption: The authorities consider that the outbreak is under control.  It was going to be a party.  And it started as such.  But after guests at the wedding of a Venezuelan couple in the Dominican Republic ate lobster, nothing was the same.  A few days later, cholera would return to Venezuela after an absence of ten years.  The government had to implement a prevention campaign to deal with the cholera outbreak.  The authorities consider that it is now under control.  However, some doctors say that if the epidemic siege is not fully controlled, autochthonous cases could originate.  The "cholera of the rich" also affected the rest of the inhabitants of Caracas in some way, since the mobile food stalls received inspections from the health authorities.  And, for now, the capital's hot dogs and hamburgers are sold without lettuce or tomato.  Casa de Campo not only has an international airport but also its golf courses, polo fields, a private beach, museums and even a replica of a medieval town.  More than 500 wedding guests arrived there on January 22: 452 were Venezuelans.  Everything was prepared for a great celebration.  But one detail changed everything: among the main dishes was lobster, from the Pedernales region, on the border with Haiti, a country that has suffered a cholera epidemic since October that affected 200,000 people and caused the death of another 4,000.  BBC Mundo unsuccessfully tried to contact Casa de Campo to find out their version of events.  The vast majority of the guests returned to Venezuela.  Some already had cholera.  But they returned on private or charter flights.  Therefore, the country's airport authorities could do little.  On January 26, the first 21 cases were confirmed.  The alarms went off and the health authorities implemented a prevention plan.  A campaign began in the media and controls were reinforced in hospitals, air terminals, and ports.  So far 252 people have been treated, of which 28 have had to be hospitalized and 64 received outpatient treatment.  The Minister of Health, Eugenia Sader, called for the guests to undergo medical studies.  And although the wedding organizers provided a guest list, it is not known for certain who attended.  "It was difficult to call the 452 people because most of them traveled on private flights.  We asked the event organizers for the list of guests, we called the list of commercial flights and alerted the press that attendees should receive treatment," the minister told the newspaper El Universal.  Sader said she was "almost certain that all of the patients received the treatment."  "But out of pity or something they haven't reported it," he added.  So far there have been no autochthonous cases and to ensure that the situation is kept under control, a nationwide study will be carried out to verify that the bacterium in the  vibrio cholerae  is not circulating in the country, Sader told Venezolana de Televisión.  However, not everyone is confident that the outbreak is under control.  The former Minister of Health (1997-1999), José Félix Oletta, told BBC Mundo that he will not be "calm until all the guests are identified and treated."  "The outbreak cannot be considered absolutely controlled (...) It is possible that they infect relatives and relatives," Oletta said, adding that "autochthonous cases may occur."  Mobile food stalls in Caracas cannot use tomato, lettuce or cabbage.  Minister Sader confirmed that this outbreak originating from the wedding also traveled to Spain – where two cases were reported – and to Mexico.  And the United States did not escape: Boston (two cases) and New York (three) suffered from the contaminated lobster.  But the inhabitants of Caracas also experience the consequences firsthand.  The so-called "Hunger Street" around Plaza Venezuela, is populated with street stalls that have been forced to slightly modify their gastronomic offer.  Humberto, from the Los Primos post, tells BBC Mundo that they have received "several visits from the Ministry of Health and the Caracas mayor's office."  They were banned from using cabbage, lettuce, and tomato in their hamburgers and hot dogs.  And they asked them to extreme hygienic conditions.  But Humberto says that people continue to approach the position as always.  And he adds that he is the one who has to remind customers that "La diabla" -a popular dish- comes with a few less ingredients.  "With the chorizo, the chicken and the meat that 'La diabla' has, nobody asks about the taste of the cabbage," he explains.
en.L0C04FQG5: Learn details of how and where the cholera outbreak that arrived in Venezuela was generated  The night of the wedding had arrived at the exclusive resort anchored in the Caribbean city of La Romana, in the Dominican Republic, on Saturday, January 22.  The party was prepared to receive about 500 people, most of them from Venezuela, since the bride and groom are Mercedes Borberg and Raúl Zajía from Caracas. There were also guests from the United States, Mexico and Spain.  The two-day celebration began with a bachelor party at a private residence in Casa de Campo, and continued on Saturday in La Romana with the celebration of the ecclesiastical union between one of the daughters of doña Carmen Mendoza and the son of the doctor Eduardo Borberg, as reported in the Dominican newspapers.  But silently, the Vibrio cholerae bacterium, which transmits the cholera virus, a disease that causes an acute intestinal infection that can cause death from dehydration, had slipped into the private party.  Neighboring Haiti has been plagued by this easily transmitted virus since October 2010, with more than 4,000 deaths.  In the same Dominican Republic there have been, since the beginning of the crisis in Haiti, 291 cases in treatment.  That Saturday the 22nd, at the other end of the island shared by the two nations, those attending the wedding ate and congratulated the couple.  A Venezuelan orchestra enlivened the atmosphere.  Among the attendees were businessman Fernando Hazoury and Manuel Peynado, son of former Dominican Vice President Jacinto Peynado.  They served sushi, shellfish, fish, and pasta, but lobster was offered among the main courses.  Almost everyone who attended ate it, even the son of one of the employees who attended the banquet tried the food that his mother brought home later.  Almost at dawn, the bride and groom left on a Pacific cruise, while family members and guests returned to their countries of origin.  Everything else was a matter of time.  Cholera was housed in the lobster that everyone ate, and this is the coincidental element that allowed the Dominican health authorities to know that the virus quickly attacked the group that attended the meeting in Punta Cana, Luis García revealed to this newspaper, Dominican spokesman for the Ministry of Health.  The transit of the virus began in the fishing town of Pedernales, on the southern border of the Dominican Republic with Haiti.  From there he moved, camouflaged in the presumably contaminated lobster, to the place of the banquet.  The contagion was rapid due to the same characteristics of the virus.  A total of 452 Venezuelans entered the risk registers, of which there are 37 confirmed and under medical treatment.  In the Dominican Republic there were five infected, including Fernando Hazoury and Manuel Peynado, admitted to the Hospiten clinic in La Romana.  The boy who ate the lobster his mother brought home is also under medical control.  Two other islanders have not been identified.  All the media, in their different channels, began to review the news four days later, when the Venezuelan Minister of Health, Eugenia Sader, confirmed the first cases and the origin of the contagion.  The outbreaks of the disease were concentrated in the Capital District, Miranda and Barquisimeto.  The news also triggered various rumors, many without sources or support, to such an extent that the Venezuelan businessman Gustavo Cisneros issued a statement yesterday afternoon in which he expressed himself outside of what happened and regretted the fact: " We inform you that the Cisneros Family has no connection to the case, or to the event, and that it did not occur at their residence or on any of their properties."  The risk is latent, because the virus can remain active, without manifesting itself, in any of the guests.  All are considered by the authorities as suspected of having the disease, and for this stage of risk there is treatment and a protocol that will prevent its spread to family members and other Venezuelans.  With information from: Aporrea.org
en.L0C04FQG1: Health confirms only 9 were infected with cholera  The Dominican government confirmed yesterday that nine people, seven Venezuelans and two Dominicans, became infected with cholera by consuming a lobster that was served during a wedding that took place last Saturday in the eastern region of the country.  The information was released by the Minister of Public Health, Bautista Rojas Gómez, who went to the National Palace to render a report to Vice President Rafael Alburquerque, after an exhaustive investigation was carried out and those affected were subjected to local examinations.  Rojas Gómez said that to those nine infected are added five Venezuelans who, after leaving the party, traveled to their country, and that after alerting them from the Dominican authorities, they underwent tests in Venezuela, where they tested positive for the bacteria that causes the disease.  The Minister of Health revealed that since last Monday the state institution knew about the case and that it had not disclosed the details because they were waiting for the results of the exams.  Rojas Gómez reported that the nine positive cases of cholera were registered among more than 500 people who participated in the private activity in a residence in the eastern region of the country.  He explained that the investigation determined that the contagion was due to the ingestion of lobsters from the coasts of Pedernales, which were not properly cooked.  The official stated that so far there are no indications that other cases of the disease could occur directly linked to the situation presented.  He said that the Public Health authorities have the cholera situation under control, to prevent the spread of the disease.  "We communicated the situation to the Pan American Health Organization, both to the local representation and to the headquarters in Washington, to the National Center of Venezuela, and the Rapid Response Team of the Ministry of Health was activated, beginning an in-depth investigation," he said. Rojas Gomez.  He stressed that the health authorities of the Dominican Republic have acted correctly, strictly following the provisions of the International Health Regulations, of which it is a signatory.  Gastroenterologist The gastroenterologist Fernando Contreras, who takes care of Dominicans affected by cholera in the country after participating in a wedding with a group of Venezuelans, affirmed yesterday that the patients are out of danger, after overcoming the problems of vomiting, diarrhea and dehydration they presented.  Meanwhile, the Dominican Medical Association (CMD) criticized the way in which Public Health handled the information related to that case and urged the authorities to be more transparent, since this undermines trust.  Another 38 Venezuelans who were in the activity in the Dominican Republic were confirmed with cholera in their country.  (+) REACTION OF CISNEROS AND CASA DE CAMPO The Casa de Campo hotel and Costasur Dominicana clarified yesterday that all food, drinks, ice and other provisions served at a private wedding party held in one of their private residences within their resort , where cases of poisoning were registered, were not provided by them.  After expressing concern for the people affected, they reiterated to their owners and clients that they can continue to have the trust they have placed during all these years.  While the Cisneros family affirmed yesterday that it has no connection with the case in which a group of people were affected at the aforementioned party.  In a press release, under the signature of Mrs. Antonieta López, Vice President of Corporate Affairs of the Cisneros Organization, says that he regrets the situation that these people are going through.  Press outlets had reported that the party was held in a villa owned by Venezuelan businessman Gustavo Cisneros.
en.L0C04FQG6: More cases of cholera in the Dominican  The Ministry of Public Health of the Dominican Republic reported another 31 cases of cholera, bringing the total affected to 269 people.  Newsroom of CiberCuba  The Ministry of Public Health of the Dominican Republic reported another 31 cases of cholera, bringing the total affected to 269 people.  Of these, 12 were infected at a wedding party of Venezuelans in La Romana, after eating seafood that was not well cooked, according to Dominican health authorities.  In addition, another 16 cases with epidemiological links are being investigated, who participated in the party in different circumstances.  Of the 12 infected in the celebration, nine are Venezuelans and three Dominicans, of whom only one was admitted.  It is estimated that close to 500 Venezuelans participated in the wedding in La Romana, of which 119 were detected with the cholera bacterium in their country.  The Dominican ministry said it was in daily contact via video-conference with the Venezuelan authorities to monitor and control those affected.  In addition to the Venezuelans, it is feared that Dominican employees who worked at the ceremony may have contracted the disease.  On the other hand, it was announced here that Venezuela assured that it will not limit the trips of its citizens to the Dominican Republic due to this situation.  The ambassador of Caracas in Santo Domingo, Alfredo Muga Rivas, discussed the case this Saturday with the Dominican vice president, Rafael Alburquerque, the promptness and effectiveness with which the authorities of both countries handled the situation.  This outbreak of cholera led the Casa de Campo hotel in La Romana, where most of the wedding attendees were staying, to put out an announcement in the media that all drinks and food for the ceremony had been contracted by the host of the wedding. party to third parties and none came from the hotel company. en.L0C04FQG2: Five Venezuelans contract cholera during a party in the DR  Venezuelan authorities yesterday confirmed at least five cases of cholera in the country, in people who contracted the virus at a party they attended in the Dominican Republic over the weekend.  "We have suspected cases and positive cases of cholera in the country," Health Minister Eugenia Sader said in a statement to the press in which she did not specify the precise number of people who were positively detected for the virus.  However, Venezuelan President Hugo Chávez said that there were "five" confirmed cases of cholera, during an official ceremony broadcast on state television.  Minister Sader explained to the press that 21 people with symptoms of "profuse diarrhea and significant fluid loss" were being treated at three clinics in Caracas.  Adolfino Sáenz, medical director of one of those clinics, the La Trinidad Teaching Center, told Efe that nine people came to that medical center with severe diarrhea, three were discharged and the other six remain hospitalized due to dehydration.  Saenz stressed that at the moment there is "clinical suspicion" that the patients contracted cholera, but to determine whether or not they suffer from the disease, we will have to wait until tomorrow, Thursday (today), when the results of some analyzes carried out by the Institute will be known. National Hygiene (INH).  Sader told the press on Wednesday that another 12 Venezuelans are receiving treatment in the Dominican Republic, whose authorities confirmed that the food served at the celebration last weekend "was contaminated" with the cholera virus.  All those affected patients attended the celebration in the Dominican Republic, said Sader, who asked the rest of the people who attended the party to appear at the health centers to be evaluated because sometimes the disease can be asymptomatic, as he explained.  Sader ruled out the possibility of an epidemic, due, he said, to the fact that the country has a large and excellent drinking water system.  "The risk is low in Venezuela of being able to have an epidemic," declared the minister, who nevertheless called on the population to exercise extreme personal and food hygiene to avoid any contagion.  The transmission of the cholera virus is only through food contaminated with feces, the spread is halted if standards such as hand washing and taking hygienic measures with food are complied with, he reiterated.  He also stressed that the treatment of cholera, which consists of the administration of a single dose of a medication, is free in Venezuela.  Sader reported that people can attend the Comprehensive Diagnostic Centers of Barrio Adentro de Chuao, Santa Cruz, La California Norte and Altagracia to report to be examined and receive treatment for free.  He said that the disease can be lethal quickly and assured that the State has treatment for some 10,000 people, which is simple and consists of a single dose.  "Once treatment is received, there is no chance that the patient will relapse," he added.  The minister said that the family that held the meeting is preparing the list with the names of all the people who attended the party.  "We must create an epidemiological fence to prevent the disease from being transmitted to people who did not attend the event," he added.  Sader considered hygiene in food and hand washing essential.  Dominicans LISTÍN DIARIO learned that of the 15 to 20 Dominicans who attended the event, at least two are in delicate health conditions, both hospitalized in two private healthcare centers in the National District, and one of them in the intensive care unit.  The relative of one of the affected Dominican patients told LISTÍN DIARIO that the people, mostly foreigners, were affected at the wedding of a Venezuelan who chose La Romana to celebrate it.  (+) A PARTY WAS ATTENDED BY 500 GUESTS The Venezuelan Health Minister, Eugenia Sader, said that people were infected at a party in the Dominican Republic, which an estimated 500 Venezuelans attended.  There are 21 infected Venezuelans in the country and 12 in the Dominican Republic.  The Ministry of Health assures that it has the treatment to treat the disease.  He reported that 12 Venezuelans are receiving treatment in the Dominican Republic, 13 went to a private clinic in Trinidad, 5 in La Castellana and three in San Bernardino.  He said that the ministry calls on all the people who attended the party (he did not specify which party) to contact the number 0800-VIGILAN to have a check-up regardless of whether they do not present symptoms.  He said the main symptom is diarrhea.  Apart from informing the media, the minister will communicate with the population.  He said that some of these people are in Madrid, Mexico and Boston.
en.L0C04FJPX: Dominican authorities will burn food from Haiti without a health certificate  The Dominican government warned Monday that it will incinerate raw food of animal origin from Haiti that lacks a sanitary certificate, as a measure to prevent the spread of cholera.  The Minister of Health, Bautista Rojas, explained that the purpose of the provision is to prevent food that may be contaminated with the bacteria from entering the Dominican market clandestinely.  Rojas had reported that the consumption of semi-raw lobsters brought from Haiti had been the cause of the massive contagion of cholera in more than 300 Venezuelans who attended a wedding held on January 22 in a luxurious tourist complex in the east of the country.  According to the report by the health authorities, the lobsters were purchased from Haitian fishermen in the Pedernales province, on the border with Haiti and on whose coast the largest fishing of these crustaceans is carried out.  Fishermen from Haiti and the Dominican Republic also used to exchange their products in an informal market on Beata Island, located 7 kilometers off the coast of Pedernales.  Due to the informality of this trade, the Export and Investment Center of the Dominican Republic lacks statistics on the importation of shellfish from Haiti.  Rojas warned that the armed forces, including the navy, are authorized to confiscate and destroy all raw food of animal origin that is trafficked into the Dominican Republic without a sanitary authorization.  In addition to the seafood trade in Pedernales, thousands of Dominicans and Haitians come to exchange their products in the various binational markets that are held twice a week at various points along the border.  Since cholera began to spread, the health authorities of the Dominican Republic have prohibited the sale of homemade food and non-bottled drinks in border markets and established hygiene measures for attendees.  Cholera, which is transmitted through the consumption of food or drinks with traces of fecal matter, has caused some 4,500 deaths in Haiti and has affected another 215,000 people in that country.  In the Dominican Republic, three deaths and just over 400 people affected have been reported since the epidemic began in late October.
en.L0C04FQFZ: Public Health confirms nine cases of cholera at the La Romana party  SANTO DOMINGO, RD.- The Ministry of Public Health reported this Thursday the confirmation of nine positive cases of cholera among the more than 500 people who participated in a private activity in a private residence in the Eastern Region.  At a press conference, the Minister of Public Health, Dr. Bautista Rojas Gómez, reported that all those affected are out of danger, and that the authorities have everything under control to prevent the spread of the disease.  He affirmed that so far there are no indications that other cases of the disease could occur directly linked to the situation presented.  He said that the investigation determined that the contagion was due to the ingestion of lobsters from the coasts of Pedernales, which were not properly cooked.  He specified that until now they have determined failures in the refrigeration chain, in addition to the fact that the seafood was not properly cooked.  He said that the Dominican authorities maintain contact with PAHO and the Venezuelan authorities regarding the situation, which he insisted is under strict control.  He observed that among those affected is a son of a woman who works in the residence where the party was held, who took part of the food home.  Rojas Gómez stressed that the health authorities of the Dominican Republic have acted correctly, strictly following the provisions of the International Health Regulations, of which it is a signatory.  In this regard, when explaining the chronology of events, he pointed out that the private party took place last Saturday, and that the period and incubation was between eight and 48 hours.  He added that on Tuesday of this week, they communicated the situation to the Pan American Health Organization, to the local representation as well as to the headquarters in Washington; to the National Center of Venezuela and activated the Rapid Response Team of the country's Ministry of Health, beginning an in-depth investigation.  The recommendations  He indicated that the Ministry of Public Health has established all relevant controls, but alerted the general population to follow the recommendations of the place to prevent cholera and other common diseases in the country.  He cited eating well-cooked food and keeping food preparation areas clean, and drinking boiled or chlorinated water.  He also referred to washing hands with soap and water, before eating, handling food, after going to the bathroom or latrine, or changing diapers.

es.L0C04G4DT: Venezuela le hace frente al "cólera de los ricos"   Fuente de la imagen, AFP  Pie de foto, Las autoridades consideran que el brote está controlado.   Iba a ser una fiesta. Y empezó como tal. Pero luego de que los invitados a la boda de una pareja venezolana en República Dominicana comieron langosta, ya nada fue igual. Pocos días después el cólera volvería a Venezuela tras una ausencia de diez años.  El gobierno debió implementar una campaña de prevención para hacerle frente al brote de cólera. Las autoridades consideran que ahora está controlado.  Sin embargo, algunos médicos aseguran que si el cerco epidémico no es controlado totalmente se podrían originar casos autóctonos.  El "cólera de los ricos" también afectó de alguna manera al resto de los habitantes de Caracas, pues los puestos ambulantes de comida recibieron inspecciones de las autoridades sanitarias.  Y, por ahora, los perros calientes y hamburguesas de la capital se venden sin lechuga ni tomate.  Casa de Campo no sólo cuenta con aeropuerto internacional sino que a sus campos de golf se le suman canchas de polo, una playa privada, museos y hasta una réplica de un pueblo medieval.  Hasta allí llegaron el 22 de enero más de 500 invitados a una boda: 452 eran venezolanos.  Todo estaba preparado para una gran celebración. Pero un detalle cambió todo: entre los platos principales había langosta, proveniente de la región de Pedernales, en la frontera con Haití, país que sufre desde octubre una epidemia de cólera que afectó a 200.000 personas y causó la muerte de otras 4.000.  BBC Mundo intentó infructuosamente comunicarse con Casa de Campo para conocer su versión de los hechos.  La gran mayoría de los invitados volvió a Venezuela. Algunos ya tenían cólera. Pero volvieron en vuelos privados o chárter. Por ello, las autoridades aeroportuarias del país poco pudieron hacer.  El 26 de enero se confirmaron los primeros 21 casos. Se dispararon las alarmas y las autoridades sanitarias implementaron un plan de prevención.  Se comenzó a hacer una campaña en medios de comunicación y se reforzaron controles en hospitales, terminales aéreas y portuarias.  Hasta ahora 252 personas fueron tratadas, de las cuales 28 debieron ser hospitalizadas y 64 recibieron tratamiento ambulatorio.  La ministra de Salud, Eugenia Sader, hizo un llamado a que los invitados se hicieran estudios médicos.  Y aunque los organizadores de la boda entregaron una lista de invitados, no se conoce con certeza quiénes asistieron.  "Era difícil llamar a las 452 personas porque la mayoría viajó en vuelos privados. Pedimos la lista de invitados a los organizadores del evento, llamamos a la lista de vuelos comerciales y alertamos por la prensa que los asistentes debían recibir tratamiento", le dijo la ministra al diario El Universal.  Sader dijo estar "casi segura de que la totalidad de los pacientes recibieron el tratamiento". "Pero por pena o algo no lo han reportado", agregó.  Hasta ahora no se han registrado casos autóctonos y para asegurarse de que la situación se mantenga bajo control se realizará un estudio a nivel nacional para comprobar que la bacteria del  vibrio cholerae  no esté circulando por el país, dijo Sader a Venezolana de Televisión.  Sin embargo, no todos confían en que el brote esté controlado.  El ex ministro de Salud (1997-1999), José Félix Oletta, le dijo a BBC Mundo que no va a estar "tranquilo hasta que todos los invitados sean identificados y tratados".  "El brote no se puede considerar absolutamente controlado (…) Es posible que contagien a familiares y allegados", aseguró Oletta, quien agregó que "es posible que se den casos autóctonos".  Los puestos ambulantes de comida en Caracas no pueden usar tomate, lechuga ni repollo.   La ministra Sader confirmó que este brote originado en la boda también viajó a España –donde se reportaron dos casos– y a México. Y Estados Unidos no se escapó: Boston (dos casos) y Nueva York (tres) sufrieron la langosta contaminada.  Pero los habitantes de Caracas también viven en carne propia las consecuencias.  La llamada "Calle del hambre" en torno a la Plaza Venezuela, está poblada de puestos ambulantes que se han visto obligados a modificar levemente su oferta gastrónómica.  Humberto, del puesto Los Primos, le dice a BBC Mundo que han recibido "varias visitas del Ministerio de Salud y de la alcaldía de Caracas".  Les prohibieron el uso de repollo, lechuga y tomate en sus hamburguesas y perros calientes. Y les pidieron que extremaran las condiciones de higiene.  Pero Humberto dice que la gente se sigue acercando al puesto como siempre. Y agrega que es él quien tiene que recordar a los clientes que "La diabla" -un popular plato- viene con algunos ingredientes menos.  "Con el chorizo, el pollo y la carne que llevan 'La diabla', nadie pregunta por el sabor del repollo", explica.
es.L0C04FQG5: Conozca detalles de cómo y dónde se generó el brote de cólera que llegó a Venezuela    La noche de la boda había llegado en el exclusivo complejo turístico anclado en la ciudad caribeña de La Romana, en la República Dominicana, el sábado 22 de enero. La fiesta fue preparada para recibir a cerca de 500 personas, la mayoría provenientes de Venezuela, pues los novios son los caraqueños Mercedes Borberg y Raúl Zajía.También había invitados procedentes de los Estados Unidos, México y España. La celebración, de dos días, comenzó con la despedida de solteros en una residencia privada en Casa de Campo, y siguió el sábado en La Romana con la celebración de la unión eclesiástica entre una de las hijas de doña Carmen Mendoza y el hijo del doctor Eduardo Borberg, según trascendió en los diarios dominicanos.  Pero silenciosamente, a la fiesta privada, se había colado la bacteria del Vibrio cholerae, transmisora del virus del cólera, enfermedad que provoca una aguda infección intestinal que puede producir la muerte por deshidratación.  La vecina Haití es azotada por este virus de fácil transmisión desde octubre de 2010, con más de 4.000 muertos. En la misma República Dominicana ha habido, desde que se inició la crisis en Haití, 291 casos en tratamiento.  Ese sábado 22, al otro extremo de la isla que comparten las dos naciones, los asistentes a la boda comían y felicitaban a los novios. Una orquesta venezolana amenizaba el ambiente. Entre los asistentes se encontraban el empresario Fernando Hazoury y Manuel Peynado, hijo del ex vicepresidente dominicano Jacinto Peynado.  Sirvieron sushi, mariscos, pescado y pasta, pero entre los platos principales se ofreció langosta. Casi todos los que asistieron la comieron, incluso el hijo de una de las empleadas que atendió el banquete probó el alimento que su mamá llevó más tarde a casa.  Casi al amanecer, los novios partieron en un crucero por el Pacífico, mientras que los familiares e invitados regresaron a sus países de origen. Todo lo demás era asunto de tiempo. El cólera estaba alojado en la langosta que todos comieron, y este es el elemento coincidente que permitió a las autoridades sanitarias de Dominicana, saber que el virus atacó rápidamente al grupo que acudió a la cita de Punta Cana, reveló a este diario Luis García, vocero dominicano del ministerio de sanidad.  El tránsito del virus comenzó en el pueblo pesquero de Pedernales, en la frontera sur de Dominicana con Haití. De allí se trasladó, camuflado en la langosta presuntamente contaminada, hasta el lugar del banquete.  El contagio fue rápido por las mismas característica del virus. Un total de 452 venezolanos entraron en los registros de riesgo, de los cuales hay 37 confirmados y en tratamiento médico.  En Dominicana hubo cinco infectados, entre quienes se encuentran Fernando Hazoury y Manuel Peynado, internados en la clínica Hospiten, en La Romana. El niño que consumió la langosta que su madre llevó a su casa, también está en control médico. Otros dos isleños no han sido identificados.  Todos los medios de comunicación, en sus distintos canales, comenzaron a reseñar la noticia cuatro días más tarde, cuando la ministra de Salud de Venezuela, Eugenia Sader, confirmó los primeros casos y el origen del contagio. Los focos de la enfermedad se concentraron en Distrito Capital, Miranda y Barquisimeto.  La noticia también desencadenó diversos rumores, muchos sin fuentes ni asidero, a tal punto que el empresario venezolano Gustavo Cisneros emitió, en horas de la tarde de ayer, un comunicado en el que se expresaba al margen de lo sucedido y lamentó el hecho: "Les informamos que la Familia Cisneros no tiene ninguna vinculación en el caso, ni con el evento, y que el mismo no ocurrió en su residencia ni en ninguna de sus propiedades".  El riesgo es latente, porque el virus puede permanecer activo, sin que se manifieste, en cualquiera de los invitados. Todos están considerados por las autoridades como sospechosos de tener la enfermedad, y para esta etapa de riesgo existe tratamiento y un protocolo que evitará su propagación a familiares y a otros venezolanos.  Con información de: Aporrea.org
es.L0C04FQG1: Salud confirma sólo 9 se infectaron de cólera   El gobierno dominicano confirmó ayer que nueve personas, siete venezolanos y dos dominicanos, se infectaron de cólera al consumir una langosta que fue servida durante una boda efectuada el pasado sábado en la región Este del país.  La información la dio a conocer el ministro de Salud Pública, Bautista Rojas Gómez, quien acudió al Palacio Nacional a rendir un informe al vicepresidente Rafael Alburquerque, luego de que se realizara una exhaustiva investigación y se les practicaran los exánimes de lugar a los afectados.  Rojas Gómez dijo que a esos nueve infectados se agregan cinco venezolanos que tras salir de la fiesta viajaron a su país, y que previa alerta de las autoridades dominicanas, les fueron practicados exámenes en Venezuela, donde dieron positivo a la bacteria que produce la enfermedad.  El ministro de Salud reveló que desde el pasado lunes la institución estatal conocía del caso y que no había dado a conocer los detalles porque esperaban los resultados de los exámenes.  Rojas Gómez informó que los nueve casos positivos de cólera se registraron entre más de 500 personas que participaron en la actividad privada en una residencia en la región Este del país.  Explicó que la investigación determinó que el contagio obedeció a la ingesta de langostas procedentes de las costas de Pedernales, las cuales no estuvieron debidamente cocidas.  El funcionario afirmó que hasta el momento no hay indicios de que pudieran ocurrir otros casos de la enfermedad vinculados directamente con la situación presentada.  Dijo que las autoridades de Salud Pública tienen la situación del cólera bajo control, para evitar la propagación de la enfermedad.  "Comunicamos la situación a la Organización Panamericana de la Salud, tanto a la representación local como a la sede de Washington, al Centro Nacional de Venezuela, y se activó el Equipo de Respuesta Rápida del Ministerio de Salud, iniciándose una profunda investigación", sostuvo Rojas Gómez.  Destacó que las autoridades sanitarias de la República Dominicana han actuado correctamente, siguiendo estrictamente lo establecido en el Reglamento Sanitario Internacional, del cual es signataria.  Gastroenterólogo El gastroenterólogo Fernando Contreras quien tiene bajo su cuidado a los dominicanos afectados de cólera en el país tras participar en una boda junto a un grupo de venezolanos, afirmó ayer que los pacientes se encuentran fuera de peligro, tras superar los problemas de vómitos, diarrea y deshidratación que presentaban.  En tanto, el Colegio Médico Dominicano (CMD) criticó la forma en que Salud Pública manejó la información relacionada a ese caso y conminó a las autoridades a ser más trasparentes, ya que con eso se merma la confianza.  Otros 38 venezolanos que estuvieron en la actividad en República Dominicana fueron confirmados con cólera en su país.  (+) REACCIÓN DE CISNEROS Y DE CASA DE CAMPO El hotel Casa de Campo y Costasur Dominicana aclararon ayer que todos los alimentos, bebidas, hielo y demás provisiones servidos en una fiesta de bodas privada realizada en una de sus residencias privadas dentro de su resort, donde se registraron casos de intoxicaciones, no fueron provistos por ellos.  Tras expresar preocupación por las personas afectadas, reiteraron a sus propietarios y clientes que pueden continuar teniendo la confianza que han depositado durante todos estos años.  En tanto que la familia Cisneros afirmó ayer que no tiene ninguna vinculación con el caso en el que resultaron afectados un grupo de personas en la referida fiesta.  En un comunicado de prensa, bajo la firma de la señora Antonieta López, vicepresidente de Asuntos Corporativos de la Organización Cisneros dice que lamenta la situación por la que atraviesan esas personas.  Medios de prensa habían informado que la fiesta fue celebrada en una villa propiedad del empresario venezolano Gustavo Cisneros.
es.L0C04FQG6: Más casos de cólera en Dominicana   El ministerio de Salud Pública de República Dominicana reportó otros 31 casos de cólera, que elevan el total de afectados a 269 personas.   Redacción de CiberCuba      El ministerio de Salud Pública de República Dominicana reportó otros 31 casos de cólera, que elevan el total de afectados a 269 personas. De estos, 12 se infectaron en una fiesta de boda de unos venezolanos en La Romana, después de ingerir mariscos que no estaban bien cocidos, según autoridades sanitarias dominicanas. Además, se investigan otros 16 casos con nexos epidemiológicos, que participaron en la fiesta en diferentes circunstancias. De los 12 infectados en la celebración, nueve son venezolanos y tres dominicanos, de los cuales solo quedaba uno ingresado. Se estima que cerca de 500 venezolanos participaron en la boda de La Romana, de ellos 119 detectados con la bacteria del cólera en su país. El ministerio dominicano dijo estar en contacto diario mediante video-conferencia con las autoridades venezolanas para dar seguimiento y control a los afectados. Además de los venezolanos, se teme que empleados dominicanos que trabajaron en la ceremonia pudieran haber contraído la enfermedad. Por otra parte, se dio a conocer aquí que Venezuela aseguró que no limitará los viajes de sus ciudadanos a República Dominicana por esta situación. El embajador de Caracas en Santo Domingo, Alfredo Muga Rivas, trató el caso este sábado con el vicepresidente dominicano, Rafael Alburquerque, la prontitud y efectividad con que las autoridades de ambos países manejaron la situación. Este brote de cólera indujo al hotel Casa de Campo de La Romana, donde se alojaba la mayoría de los asistentes a la boda, a sacar un anuncio en los medios que todas las bebidas y comidas de la ceremonia habían sido contratadas por el anfitrión de la fiesta a terceras personas y ninguna procedió de la empresa hotelera. es.L0C04FQG2: Cinco venezolanos contraen el cólera durante fiesta en RD   Las autoridades venezolanas confirmaron ayer al menos cinco casos de cólera en el país, en personas que se contagiaron del virus en una fiesta a la que asistieron en República Dominicana el fin de semana.  "Tenemos casos sospechosos y casos positivos de cólera en el país", dijo la ministra de Salud, Eugenia Sader, en una declaración a la prensa en la que no especificó el número preciso de personas a las que se le detectó positivamente el virus.  Sin embargo, el presidente venezolano, Hugo Chávez, dijo que eran "cinco" los casos confirmados de cólera, durante un acto oficial transmitido por la televisión estatal.  La ministra Sader detalló a la prensa que 21 personas con síntomas de "diarrea profusa y pérdida importante de líquidos" estaban siendo atendidas en tres clínicas de Caracas.  Adolfino Sáenz, director médico de una de esas clínicas, el Centro Docente La Trinidad, dijo a Efe que nueve personas acudieron a ese centro médico con fuerte diarrea, tres fueron dadas de alta y las otras seis permanecen hospitalizadas debido a la deshidratación que sufren.  Saenz destacó que de momento existe la "sospecha clínica" de que los pacientes contrajeron el cólera, pero para determinar si padecen o no la enfermedad habrá que esperar a mañana jueves (hoy), cuando se conocerán los resultados de unos análisis que realiza el Instituto Nacional de Higiene (INH).  Sader dijo a la prensa este miércoles que otros 12 venezolanos reciben tratamiento en República Dominicana, cuyas autoridades confirmaron que la comida que se sirvió en la celebración del fin de semana pasado "estaba contaminada" con el virus del cólera.  Todos esos pacientes afectados asistieron a la celebración en República Dominicana, sostuvo Sader, que pidió al resto de las personas que acudieron a la fiesta presentarse en los centros de salud para ser evaluados porque en ocasiones la enfermedad puede ser asintomática, según explicó.  Sader descartó la posibilidad de una epidemia, debido -dijo- a que el país cuenta con un amplio y excelente sistema de agua potable.  "El riesgo es bajo en Venezuela de poder tener una epidemia", declaró la ministra, que sin embargo llamó a la población a extremar la higiene personal y de los alimentos para evitar algún contagio.  La transmisión del virus del cólera es solo a través de los alimentos contaminados con heces fecales, la propagación se paraliza si se cumple con normas como el lavado de la manos y la toma de medidas higiénicas con los alimentos, reiteró.  También resaltó que el tratamiento del cólera, que consiste en la administración de una única dosis de un medicamento, es gratuito en Venezuela.  Sader informó que las personas pueden asistir a los Centros de Diagnóstico Integral de Barrio Adentro de Chuao, Santa Cruz, La California Norte y Altagracia a reportarse para ser examinadas y recibir el tratamiento de forma gratuita. Dijo que la enfermedad puede ser letal rápidamente y aseguró que el Estado cuenta con tratamiento para unas 10.000 personas, que es sencillo y está conformado por una sola dosis. "Una vez que se recibe el tratamiento, no hay ninguna probabilidad de que el paciente recaiga", agregó.  La ministra dijo que la familia que realizó la reunión está elaborando el listado con el nombre de todas las personas que acudieron a la fiesta. "Debemos hacer un cerco epidemiológico para evitar que la enfermedad sea transmitida a personas que no asistieron al evento", agregó. Sader consideró fundamental la higiene en los alimentos y en el lavado de las manos.  Dominicanos LISTÍN DIARIO supo que de entre 15 y 20 dominicanos que asistieron al evento, por lo menos dos se encuentran en delicadas condiciones de salud, ambos hospitalizados en dos asistenciales privados del Distrito Nacional, y uno de ellos en la sala de cuidados intensivos.  El familiar de uno de los pacientes dominicanos afectados dijo a LISTÍN DIARIO que la gente, mayoritariamente extranjera, resultó afectada en la boda de un venezolano que escogió La Romana para celebrarla.  (+) A FIESTA ASISTIERON 500 INVITADOS La ministra de Salud de Venezuela, Eugenia Sader, dijo que las personas se contagiaron en una fiesta de República Dominicana, a la que se calcula asistieron unos 500 venezolanos. Hay 21 venezolanos infectados en el país y 12 en República Dominicana. El Ministerio de Salud asegura que cuenta con el tratamiento para atender la enfermedad.  Informó que 12 venezolanos están recibiendo tratamiento en República Dominicana, 13 acudieron a una clínica privada en la Trinidad, 5 en La Castellana y tres en San Bernardino.  Dijo que el ministerio hace un llamado a todas las personas que asistieron a la fiesta (no específicó qué fiesta) para que se comuniquen con el número 0800-VIGILAN para que se realicen un chequeo sin importar que no presenten los síntomas. Dijo que el principal síntoma es diarrea. Aparte de informar a los medios, la ministra se comunicará con la población. Dijo que algunas de estas personas están en Madrid, México y Boston.
es.L0C04FJPX: Autoridades dominicanas quemarán comida de Haití sin certificado sanitario   El gobierno dominicano advirtió el lunes que incinerará los alimentos crudos de origen animal procedentes de Haití que carezcan de un certificado sanitario, como medida para prevenir la propagación del cólera.  El ministro de salud, Bautista Rojas, explicó que la disposición tiene como meta evitar que los alimentos que puedan estar contaminados con la bacteria ingresen de forma clandestina al mercado dominicano.  Rojas había informado que el consumo de langostas semicrudas traídas desde Haití había sido la causa del contagio masivo con cólera de más de 300 venezolanos que asistieron a una boda celebrada el 22 de enero en un lujoso complejo turístico del este del país.  Según el reporte de las autoridades sanitarias, las langostas fueron adquiridas a pescadores haitianos en la provincia Pedernales, fronteriza con Haití y en cuya costa se realiza la mayor pesca de esos crustáceos.  Pescadores de Haití y de República Dominicana también acostumbran intercambiar sus productos en un mercado informal en la isla Beata, ubicada a 7 kilómetros de la costa de Pedernales. Debido a la informalidad de ese comercio, el Centro de Exportación e Inversión de República Dominicana carece de estadísticas sobre la importación de mariscos desde Haití.  Rojas advirtió que las fuerzas armadas, incluida la marina, están autorizadas a confiscar y destruir todo los alimentos crudos de origen animal que sean traficados hacia República Dominicana sin una autorización sanitaria.  Además del comercio de mariscos en Pedernales, miles de dominicanos y haitianos acuden a intercambiar sus productos en los diverso mercados binacionales que se realizan dos veces a la semana en diversos puntos de la frontera.  Desde que comenzó a propagarse el cólera, las autoridades sanitarias de República Dominicana prohibieron la venta de comida casera y bebidas no embotelladas en los mercados fronterizos y establecieron medidas de higiene para los asistentes. El cólera, que se transmite a través del consumo de alimentos o bebidas con restos de materia fecal, ha provocado unas 4.500 muertes en Haití y ha afectado a otras 215.000 personas en ese país. En Dominicana se han reportado tres decesos y poco más de 400 personas afectadas desde que comenzó la epidemia a finales de octubre.
es.L0C04FQFZ: Salud Pública confirma nueve casos de cólera en fiesta de La Romana   SANTO DOMINGO, RD.- El Ministerio de Salud Pública informó este jueves sobre la confirmación de nueve casos positivos de cólera entre las más de 500 personas que participaron en una actividad privada en una residencia particular en la Región Este.  En conferencia de prensa, el ministro de Salud Pública, doctor Bautista Rojas Gómez, informó que todos los afectados se encuentran fuera de peligro, y que las autoridades tiene todo bajo control para evitar la propagación de la enfermedad.  Afirmó que hasta el momento no hay indicios de que pudieran ocurrir otros casos de la enfermedad vinculados directamente con la situación presentada.  Dijo que la investigación determinó que el contagio obedeció a la ingesta de langostas procedente de las costas de Pedernales, las cuales no estuvieron debidamente cocidas.  Precisó que hasta ahora han determinado fallas en la cadena de refrigeración, en adición a que los mariscos no estaban debidamente cocidos.  Dijo que las autoridades dominicanas mantienen contacto con la OPS y las autoridades venezolanas en torno a la situación, la cual insistió está bajo estricto control.  Observó que entre los afectados figura un hijo de una señora que trabaja en la residencia en la que se celebró la fiesta, quien llevó parte de los alimentos a hogar.  Rojas Gómez destacó que las autoridades sanitarias de la República Dominicana han actuado correctamente, siguiendo estrictamente lo establecido en el Reglamento Sanitario Internacional, del cual es signataria.  Sobre el particular, al explicar la cronología de los acontecimientos, señaló que la fiesta privada se llevó a cabo el sábado pasado, y que el período e incubación estuvo entre ocho y 48 horas.  Agregó que el martes de esta semana, comunicaron la situación a la Organización Panamericana de la Salud, a la representación local como a la sede en Washington; al Centro Nacional de Venezuela y activó el Equipo de Respuesta Rápida del Ministerio de Salud del país, iniciándose una profunda investigación.  Las recomendaciones  Indicó que el Ministerio de Salud Pública ha establecido todos los controles pertinentes, pero alertó a la población en general a seguir las recomendaciones de lugar para prevenir el cólera y otras enfermedades comunes en el país.  Citó la ingesta de alimentos bien cocidos y mantener limpias las áreas de preparación de los mismos, y beber agua hervida o purificada con cloro.  Refirió, además, el lavado de manos con agua y jabón, antes de comer, de manipular comidas, después de ir al baño o letrina o cambiar pañales.
